items.text: I enjoy breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable components before attempting a solution.

items.rationale: Heightened emotional reactivity to distressing stimuli, a hallmark of sensitivity.

items.text: I can walk into a room and immediately sense tension between people.
items.rationale: Reflects acute perceptual sensitivity to interpersonal emotional dynamics.

items.text: I often need time alone to recover after emotionally charged social interactions.
items.rationale: Behavioral consequence of high emotional sensitivity—need for recovery.

items.text: Even a slightly dismissive tone from someone can make me feel rejected.
items.rationale: Reflects low threshold for perceiving and being affected by negative social cues.

items.text: I am the kind of person who tears up at heartfelt commercials or stories about kindness.
items.rationale: Behavioral indicator of high emotional sensitivity to positive emotional stimuli.

items.text: I find loud, chaotic environments emotionally overwhelming.
items.rationale: Sensory-emotional overwhelm consistent with high sensitivity.

items.text: When a friend is going through a hard time, I feel their pain almost physically.
items.rationale: Somatic empathy reflecting deep emotional sensitivity.

items.text: I have been told that I am too sensitive, but I see it as being deeply attuned to the world.
items.rationale: Self-awareness of sensitivity combined with a reframing that validates the construct.

items.text: Small acts of kindness from strangers can move me to tears.
items.rationale: Low threshold for emotional arousal in response to prosocial behavior.

items.text: I sometimes feel emotionally exhausted because I take on the feelings of those around me.
items.rationale: Emotional contagion and exhaustion; could also relate to the general Emotional factor.

items.text: I find it hard to set emotional boundaries because I care so deeply about others' wellbeing.
items.rationale: Blends emotional sensitivity with interpersonal boundary issues; some ambiguity.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of peace when the people around me are emotionally balanced and content.
items.rationale: The sensitivity to others' states maps here, but the emphasis on balance and peace could map to Harmony.

items.text: I actively participate in campaigns and petitions to protect the environment.
items.rationale: Direct behavioral indicator of environmental advocacy engagement.

items.text: I believe it is my responsibility to speak up when I see environmental destruction happening.
items.rationale: Reflects a personal construct of moral obligation to advocate for the environment.

items.text: I have contacted elected officials to urge them to support stronger environmental policies.
items.rationale: Specific advocacy behavior targeting policy change.

items.text: I try to influence the people around me to adopt more environmentally responsible habits.
items.rationale: Interpersonal advocacy behavior aimed at changing others' environmental conduct.

items.text: I use social media to raise awareness about environmental issues and mobilize support.
items.rationale: Digital advocacy behavior specifically targeting environmental causes.

items.text: I have attended protests or rallies focused on climate change or environmental protection.
items.rationale: Direct participation in collective environmental advocacy actions.

items.text: I feel a strong moral duty to fight for environmental justice, especially for vulnerable communities.
items.rationale: Combines environmental advocacy with a justice orientation.

items.text: I donate money or time to organizations that work to protect the natural world.
items.rationale: Resource commitment to environmental causes reflects active advocacy.

items.text: I believe that individual voices, when united, can force corporations to adopt greener practices.
items.rationale: Reflects a cognitive construct about the power of collective environmental advocacy.

items.text: I challenge friends and family members when they engage in environmentally harmful behaviors.
items.rationale: Interpersonal confrontation in service of environmental values.

items.text: I write letters to companies asking them to reduce their environmental footprint.
items.rationale: Specific advocacy behavior directed at corporate environmental responsibility.

items.text: I see myself as an environmental activist, even if my actions are small and local.
items.rationale: Self-identification with the activist role is central to advocacy orientation.

items.text: I make purchasing decisions based on a company's environmental track record.
items.rationale: Consumer activism is related to advocacy but could also reflect Environmental Awareness or Conservation.

items.text: I stay informed about environmental legislation so I can vote for candidates who prioritize the planet.
items.rationale: Informed voting is advocacy-adjacent but also reflects Environmental Awareness.

items.text: I feel personally responsible for reducing my carbon footprint through daily lifestyle choices.
items.rationale: Personal responsibility and daily behavior could map more to Environmental Conservation than advocacy.

items.text: I regularly think about how human activities are affecting the planet's ecosystems.
items.rationale: Cognitive preoccupation with environmental impact is the core of this construct.

items.text: I pay close attention to news about climate change, pollution, and biodiversity loss.
items.rationale: Active information-seeking about environmental issues reflects high awareness.

items.text: I understand the interconnections between deforestation, water cycles, and global weather patterns.
items.rationale: Demonstrates systems-level environmental knowledge, a cognitive marker of awareness.

items.text: I can explain the concept of a carbon footprint and why it matters to most people.
items.rationale: Environmental literacy and ability to communicate it reflects deep awareness.

items.text: I notice environmental changes in my local area, like shifts in seasonal patterns or wildlife behavior.
items.rationale: Perceptual attentiveness to local environmental changes.

items.text: I think about the environmental consequences of everyday products, from their production to disposal.
items.rationale: Life-cycle thinking about products reflects sophisticated environmental cognition.

items.text: I am aware of how my food choices impact the environment, including water use and land degradation.
items.rationale: Specific domain awareness connecting personal behavior to environmental outcomes.

items.text: I follow scientific research on topics like ocean acidification and species extinction rates.
items.rationale: Engagement with scientific environmental information reflects high awareness.

items.text: I understand that environmental problems disproportionately affect marginalized communities.
items.rationale: Awareness of environmental justice issues reflects a nuanced understanding.

items.text: I recognize that many of the products I use daily have hidden environmental costs.
items.rationale: Cognitive recognition of externalized environmental costs.

items.text: I often discuss environmental topics with friends and colleagues because they are always on my mind.
items.rationale: Frequency of environmental thinking and discussion reflects high cognitive salience.

items.text: I am knowledgeable about the difference between renewable and non-renewable energy sources.
items.rationale: Factual environmental knowledge is a direct indicator of awareness.

items.text: I feel uneasy when I see people being wasteful because I understand the environmental impact.
items.rationale: The awareness component is clear, but the emotional unease introduces affective elements.

items.text: I try to educate my children about where their food comes from and how it affects the earth.
items.rationale: Educational behavior reflects awareness but also has an advocacy component.

items.text: I feel compelled to take action whenever I learn about a new environmental threat.
items.rationale: The awareness triggers action, which maps more closely to Environmental Advocacy.

items.text: I consistently recycle, compost, and minimize waste in my household.
items.rationale: Direct behavioral indicators of conservation-oriented lifestyle.

items.text: I choose to repair items rather than replace them to reduce my environmental impact.
items.rationale: Conservation behavior focused on reducing consumption and waste.

items.text: I actively conserve water by taking shorter showers and fixing leaks promptly.
items.rationale: Specific resource conservation behavior.

items.text: I have made significant changes to my lifestyle to reduce my personal environmental footprint.
items.rationale: Reflects committed personal action toward environmental conservation.

items.text: I plant trees or maintain a garden specifically to support local biodiversity.
items.rationale: Active conservation behavior aimed at ecological restoration.

items.text: I avoid single-use plastics whenever possible and carry reusable bags and bottles.
items.rationale: Habitual waste-reduction behavior central to conservation orientation.

items.text: I choose public transportation, cycling, or walking over driving whenever I can.
items.rationale: Transportation choices reflecting commitment to reducing emissions.

items.text: I participate in local clean-up events to help preserve natural spaces in my community.
items.rationale: Direct conservation action at the community level.

items.text: I carefully consider the energy efficiency of appliances before purchasing them.
items.rationale: Consumer behavior driven by conservation values.

items.text: I believe that small, consistent conservation efforts by individuals add up to meaningful change.
items.rationale: Cognitive construct about the value of individual conservation actions.

items.text: I have reduced my meat consumption primarily because of its environmental impact.
items.rationale: Dietary change motivated by conservation concerns.

items.text: I make an effort to buy locally produced goods to reduce the carbon footprint of transportation.
items.rationale: Purchasing behavior aligned with conservation principles.

items.text: I feel guilty when I know I have been wasteful with natural resources.
items.rationale: The guilt response reflects conservation values but introduces an emotional component.

items.text: I keep track of my household's energy and water usage to identify areas for improvement.
items.rationale: Monitoring behavior is conservation-related but could also reflect general Environmental Awareness.

items.text: I wish more people understood the science behind why conservation matters so urgently.
items.rationale: The desire for others to understand maps to Environmental Awareness or Advocacy more than personal conservation behavior.

items.text: I follow international news closely because I believe events anywhere in the world can affect us all.
items.rationale: Reflects a cognitive orientation toward global interconnectedness.

items.text: I think about how policies in one country can have ripple effects across the entire globe.
items.rationale: Systems-level thinking about global political interconnections.

items.text: I am interested in learning about different cultures because it broadens my understanding of the world.
items.rationale: Cultural curiosity driven by a desire for global understanding.

items.text: I believe that global cooperation is essential to solving problems like poverty and climate change.
items.rationale: Reflects a personal construct about the necessity of international collaboration.

items.text: I consider myself a global citizen rather than just a citizen of my own country.
items.rationale: Self-identification with a global identity is central to this construct.

items.text: I am aware of how global supply chains connect my daily purchases to workers in other countries.
items.rationale: Cognitive awareness of global economic interconnections.

items.text: I try to understand geopolitical conflicts from multiple perspectives rather than just my own country's viewpoint.
items.rationale: Perspective-taking at a global level reflects sophisticated global cognition.

items.text: I feel a sense of responsibility toward people in other parts of the world, not just my own community.
items.rationale: Expanded moral circle reflecting global awareness orientation.

items.text: I actively seek out media sources from different countries to get a more balanced worldview.
items.rationale: Information-seeking behavior aimed at achieving global perspective.

items.text: I understand how migration patterns are shaped by economic inequality, conflict, and climate change.
items.rationale: Demonstrates complex understanding of global socio-political dynamics.

items.text: I think about how my lifestyle in a wealthy country may be connected to hardship in developing nations.
items.rationale: Self-reflective global awareness connecting personal privilege to global inequality.

items.text: I believe that learning a second language is valuable because it opens doors to understanding other worldviews.
items.rationale: Values linguistic diversity as a pathway to global understanding.

items.text: I feel deeply troubled when I hear about humanitarian crises in distant parts of the world.
items.rationale: The emotional response could reflect Emotional Sensitivity, though the global focus anchors it here.

items.text: I think about how international trade agreements affect both the economy and the environment worldwide.
items.rationale: Combines global awareness with environmental awareness; some construct overlap.

items.text: I believe we need to protect the world's ecosystems because environmental damage crosses all borders.
items.rationale: The global framing maps here, but the environmental content could map to Environmental Awareness.

items.text: I strive to create peaceful and balanced relationships in all areas of my life.
items.rationale: Directly reflects the pursuit of interpersonal harmony as a core personal construct.

items.text: I feel most content when there is a sense of balance between my work, relationships, and personal time.
items.rationale: Life balance as a source of contentment is central to the harmony construct.

items.text: I go out of my way to resolve disagreements before they escalate into larger conflicts.
items.rationale: Proactive conflict resolution behavior driven by a desire for harmony.

items.text: I believe that cooperation and compromise are more effective than competition and confrontation.
items.rationale: Cognitive preference for cooperative over competitive approaches reflects harmony orientation.

items.text: I am uncomfortable in environments where there is constant tension or hostility.
items.rationale: Aversion to discord reflects a strong need for harmonious environments.

items.text: I try to find common ground with people, even when we have very different opinions.
items.rationale: Bridge-building behavior motivated by a desire for interpersonal harmony.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of satisfaction when everyone in a group is getting along well.
items.rationale: Emotional reward from group harmony directly reflects this construct.

items.text: I value inner peace and regularly engage in practices like meditation or reflection to maintain it.
items.rationale: Pursuit of internal harmony through contemplative practices.

items.text: I believe that living in harmony with nature is essential for human wellbeing.
items.rationale: Extends the harmony construct to the human-nature relationship.

items.text: I prefer to work in teams where people respect each other and collaborate smoothly.
items.rationale: Workplace preference reflecting a harmony-oriented personal construct.

items.text: I often act as a mediator when friends or colleagues are in conflict.
items.rationale: Mediation behavior is a direct behavioral expression of valuing harmony.

items.text: I feel unsettled when my life feels chaotic or out of balance.
items.rationale: Negative emotional response to disharmony reflects the importance of this construct.

items.text: I sometimes avoid expressing my true opinion to keep the peace in a group.
items.rationale: Conflict avoidance is related to harmony but could also reflect low assertiveness.

items.text: I feel most at ease when I am in a calm, quiet natural setting.
items.rationale: Preference for calm environments relates to harmony but could also reflect Emotional Sensitivity.

items.text: I am very attuned to the emotional atmosphere in a room and feel distressed when it is negative.
items.rationale: The attunement to emotional atmosphere could map to Emotional Sensitivity, while the distress from negativity maps to Harmony.

items.text: I prioritize getting enough sleep because I know how much it affects my physical and mental performance.
items.rationale: Sleep prioritization reflects a health-conscious personal construct.

items.text: I make deliberate choices about what I eat because I see nutrition as foundational to my wellbeing.
items.rationale: Intentional nutritional behavior driven by health values.

items.text: I exercise regularly not just for appearance but because it makes me feel mentally and emotionally better.
items.rationale: Holistic view of exercise benefits reflects a well-developed health construct.

items.text: I believe that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my physical health.
items.rationale: Integrated view of mental and physical health is central to this construct.

items.text: I schedule regular health check-ups because I believe in prevention rather than just treatment.
items.rationale: Preventive health behavior reflects proactive health orientation.

items.text: I pay attention to how stress affects my body and take steps to manage it before it becomes a problem.
items.rationale: Stress awareness and proactive management reflect health-conscious cognition.

items.text: I view my body as something to be respected and cared for, not pushed to its limits recklessly.
items.rationale: Reflects a personal construct of bodily respect and self-care.

items.text: I limit my consumption of alcohol and processed foods because I am mindful of their long-term effects.
items.rationale: Behavioral restraint motivated by long-term health considerations.

items.text: I actively seek out information about health and wellness to make better decisions for myself and my family.
items.rationale: Health information-seeking behavior reflects high engagement with this construct.

items.text: I have established daily routines that support my overall physical and psychological wellbeing.
items.rationale: Structured health-promoting routines reflect a deeply internalized wellbeing orientation.

items.text: I believe that a healthy lifestyle is one of the most important investments a person can make.
items.rationale: Core value statement about the importance of health.

items.text: I notice when my body is telling me to slow down, and I listen to those signals.
items.rationale: Interoceptive awareness and responsive self-care behavior.

items.text: I practice mindfulness or meditation because it helps me maintain my overall sense of wellbeing.
items.rationale: Mindfulness practice relates to health and wellbeing but could also map to Harmony.

items.text: I try to spend time in nature regularly because I find it restorative for my health.
items.rationale: Nature exposure for health benefits; could also relate to Environmental Awareness or Harmony.

items.text: I find that when I am physically healthy, I am also more emotionally balanced and at peace.
items.rationale: The connection between health and emotional balance could map to Harmony as well.

items.text: I make it a priority to eat nutritious meals every day.
items.rationale: Directly addresses proactive nutritional behavior as part of overall wellness.

items.text: Maintaining a regular exercise routine is essential to how I live my life.
items.rationale: Exercise routine reflects a core construct of health and wellness orientation.

items.text: I think of physical well-being and emotional balance as deeply connected.
items.rationale: Holistic view of wellness integrating physical and emotional domains.

items.text: I regularly set goals related to improving my overall fitness and vitality.
items.rationale: Goal-setting around fitness reflects a strong wellness-oriented personal construct.

items.text: People who know me would say I'm someone who takes excellent care of my body.
items.rationale: Third-person observation style item capturing wellness reputation.

items.text: I view sleep as one of the most important investments I can make in myself.
items.rationale: Sleep prioritization is a key behavioral marker of wellness orientation.

items.text: I actively seek out information about how to live a healthier lifestyle.
items.rationale: Information-seeking about healthy living reflects cognitive engagement with wellness.

items.text: When I feel run down, I adjust my habits to restore my energy and balance.
items.rationale: Self-regulatory behavior in response to wellness cues.

items.text: I believe that daily habits are the foundation of long-term health.
items.rationale: Belief statement reflecting a core wellness construct about habit formation.

items.text: I prefer activities that challenge both my body and my mind simultaneously.
items.rationale: Integrated mind-body wellness preference.

items.text: I track my hydration, nutrition, or physical activity on a regular basis.
items.rationale: Self-monitoring behavior is a strong indicator of wellness orientation.

items.text: Wellness isn't just about not being sick—it's about thriving in every area of life.
items.rationale: Philosophical statement reflecting a broad, proactive wellness construct.

items.text: I sometimes struggle to maintain healthy habits when life gets stressful.
items.rationale: Acknowledges wellness orientation but introduces ambiguity around consistency; could relate to Mental Health.

items.text: I find that taking care of my physical health helps me manage my emotions better.
items.rationale: Bridges wellness and emotional regulation, introducing some overlap with Mental Health.

items.text: I meditate or practice mindfulness primarily to reduce my anxiety symptoms.
items.rationale: Mindfulness is a wellness practice, but the focus on anxiety symptoms pulls toward Mental Health.

items.text: I always make sure to attend my annual medical check-ups and screenings.
items.rationale: Preventive medical behavior is a core marker of health-related cognitive constructs.

items.text: I pay close attention to any changes in my body and consult a doctor when needed.
items.rationale: Body vigilance and medical help-seeking reflect health-related personal constructs.

items.text: Understanding my family's medical history is important to me for planning my own health.
items.rationale: Genetic and familial health awareness is a specific health-related cognitive orientation.

items.text: I read medical research articles to stay informed about conditions that could affect me.
items.rationale: Active engagement with medical literature reflects a health-related knowledge construct.

items.text: I am careful about following prescribed medication schedules exactly as directed.
items.rationale: Medication adherence is a classic health-related behavioral indicator.

items.text: I think about how environmental factors like air quality and water purity affect my health.
items.rationale: Environmental health awareness reflects a cognitively engaged health-related orientation.

items.text: When a new health guideline is released, I evaluate whether I need to change my behavior.
items.rationale: Responsiveness to health guidelines reflects active health-related cognition.

items.text: I keep a detailed record of my medical history and share it with new healthcare providers.
items.rationale: Medical record-keeping is a specific health-related organizational behavior.

items.text: I believe that understanding the science behind diseases helps me make better health decisions.
items.rationale: Science-based health decision-making reflects a cognitively sophisticated health-related construct.

items.text: People often come to me for advice about symptoms or which specialist to see.
items.rationale: Being a health information resource reflects strong health-related knowledge constructs.

items.text: I am very aware of the side effects and interactions of any supplements or medications I take.
items.rationale: Pharmacological awareness is a specific health-related cognitive marker.

items.text: I consider vaccination schedules and preventive treatments to be non-negotiable.
items.rationale: Commitment to preventive medicine reflects a strong health-related personal construct.

items.text: I sometimes worry excessively about potential health problems even when I feel fine.
items.rationale: Health anxiety overlaps with health-related cognition but introduces a Mental Health dimension.

items.text: I try to balance medical advice with my own intuitive sense of what my body needs.
items.rationale: Primarily health-related but the intuitive element introduces overlap with Intuition.

items.text: I research the latest wellness trends to see if they have any real medical backing.
items.rationale: Evaluating wellness trends is health-related, but the wellness framing could map to Health and Wellness.

items.text: I am always excited to try out the latest technology before most people even know about it.
items.rationale: Early adoption behavior is a hallmark of innovation and technology orientation.

items.text: I see technology as the primary driver of progress in modern society.
items.rationale: Belief in technology as a societal driver reflects a core tech-oriented construct.

items.text: I spend a significant amount of my free time exploring new software, gadgets, or platforms.
items.rationale: Leisure time devoted to tech exploration is a strong behavioral indicator.

items.text: When I encounter a problem, my first instinct is to look for a technological solution.
items.rationale: Tech-first problem-solving reflects a deeply held innovation and technology construct.

items.text: I enjoy discussing how emerging technologies like AI and blockchain will reshape industries.
items.rationale: Engagement with emerging tech discourse is a clear marker of this factor.

items.text: I believe that most of the world's biggest challenges can be solved through technological innovation.
items.rationale: Techno-optimism is a core belief within the innovation and technology construct.

items.text: I frequently automate tasks in my personal or professional life using digital tools.
items.rationale: Automation behavior reflects practical engagement with technology.

items.text: My friends would describe me as the person who always knows about the newest tech trends.
items.rationale: Third-person observation capturing social identity around technology.

items.text: I feel energized when I learn about a breakthrough in science or engineering.
items.rationale: Emotional response to scientific breakthroughs reflects tech-innovation orientation.

items.text: I actively follow technology news sources and innovation-focused podcasts.
items.rationale: Media consumption patterns reflecting sustained interest in technology.

items.text: I think coding and digital literacy should be fundamental skills taught to everyone.
items.rationale: Advocacy for tech education reflects a deeply held innovation construct.

items.text: I often prototype or build things to test out new ideas using available technology.
items.rationale: Prototyping behavior is a direct expression of innovation and technology engagement.

items.text: I am fascinated by how technology can be used to improve healthcare outcomes.
items.rationale: Primarily tech-focused but the healthcare application introduces overlap with Health-related.

items.text: I enjoy brainstorming unconventional solutions to problems, even if they don't involve technology.
items.rationale: Creative problem-solving is innovation-adjacent but the non-tech qualifier introduces ambiguity with Innovativeness.

items.text: I love coming up with completely original ideas that no one has thought of before.
items.rationale: Original ideation is innovative but not necessarily technology-specific, mapping plausibly to Innovativeness.

items.text: I constantly look for new and better ways to do things, even when the current method works fine.
items.rationale: Restless improvement-seeking is a core trait of innovativeness as a cognitive style.

items.text: I thrive when I'm given the freedom to experiment and try unconventional approaches.
items.rationale: Preference for experimentation reflects a strong innovativeness construct.

items.text: I often see possibilities and connections that others seem to miss entirely.
items.rationale: Divergent perception and pattern recognition are hallmarks of innovativeness.

items.text: I get bored quickly with routine and am always searching for a more creative way to approach tasks.
items.rationale: Boredom with routine and creative seeking are classic innovativeness markers.

items.text: People describe me as someone who thinks outside the box.
items.rationale: Third-person description capturing the social perception of innovativeness.

items.text: I believe that questioning established norms is the first step toward meaningful progress.
items.rationale: Norm-questioning as a value reflects a deep innovativeness construct.

items.text: I am comfortable with ambiguity and uncertainty when pursuing a novel idea.
items.rationale: Tolerance for ambiguity is a well-established correlate of innovativeness.

items.text: I frequently combine ideas from completely different domains to create something new.
items.rationale: Cross-domain synthesis is a cognitive hallmark of innovative thinking.

items.text: When others say something can't be done, it motivates me to find a way.
items.rationale: Contrarian motivation in the face of constraints reflects innovativeness.

items.text: I would rather fail trying something original than succeed by following a proven formula.
items.rationale: Risk preference for originality over safety is a strong innovativeness indicator.

items.text: I keep a journal or file of creative ideas that I want to explore someday.
items.rationale: Idea archiving behavior reflects sustained creative engagement.

items.text: I naturally challenge assumptions and ask 'what if' questions in every situation.
items.rationale: Assumption-challenging is a core cognitive process of innovativeness.

items.text: I find that my most creative ideas come when I'm learning something completely new.
items.rationale: Links creativity to learning, introducing some overlap with Lifelong Learning.

items.text: I often have a gut feeling about which new idea will work before I can explain why.
items.rationale: Gut-feeling about ideas is innovative but introduces overlap with Intuition.

items.text: I am driven to innovate because I want to make a positive difference in people's lives.
items.rationale: The prosocial motivation could map to Moral or Motivational factors rather than pure innovativeness.

items.text: I genuinely enjoy getting to know people on a deep, personal level.
items.rationale: Desire for deep personal connection is a core interpersonal relationship construct.

items.text: I invest a lot of time and energy into maintaining my closest friendships.
items.rationale: Relationship maintenance effort is a strong behavioral marker of this factor.

items.text: I am highly attuned to the emotional dynamics in any group I'm part of.
items.rationale: Social-emotional attunement reflects interpersonal cognitive orientation.

items.text: I believe that the quality of our relationships is the most important measure of a good life.
items.rationale: Core value statement placing relationships at the center of life meaning.

items.text: When there's conflict between people I care about, I feel compelled to help resolve it.
items.rationale: Conflict mediation drive reflects strong interpersonal engagement.

items.text: I remember small details about people's lives because I truly care about them.
items.rationale: Detail retention about others reflects cognitive investment in relationships.

items.text: I find it easy to see situations from another person's perspective.
items.rationale: Perspective-taking ability is a core interpersonal cognitive skill.

items.text: I feel most fulfilled when I'm having a meaningful conversation with someone I trust.
items.rationale: Fulfillment through meaningful dialogue reflects interpersonal orientation.

items.text: Others often tell me I'm a great listener who makes them feel heard.
items.rationale: Third-person feedback about listening skills captures interpersonal competence.

items.text: I think about how my words and actions will affect the people around me before I act.
items.rationale: Anticipatory social cognition reflects strong interpersonal awareness.

items.text: Building trust with others is something I approach with great intentionality.
items.rationale: Deliberate trust-building reflects a cognitively engaged interpersonal construct.

items.text: I feel a strong sense of responsibility toward the people in my social circle.
items.rationale: Social responsibility toward one's network is a key interpersonal construct.

items.text: I can usually sense when something is off with a friend even before they say anything.
items.rationale: Emotional sensing in relationships is interpersonal but overlaps with Intuition.

items.text: I sometimes take on other people's emotional burdens to the point where it affects my own well-being.
items.rationale: Over-involvement in others' emotions is interpersonal but introduces a Mental Health dimension.

items.text: I believe it is morally wrong to betray someone's trust, no matter the circumstances.
items.rationale: Trust loyalty is interpersonal, but the moral framing maps plausibly to the Moral factor.

items.text: I frequently rely on my gut feelings when making important decisions.
items.rationale: Gut-feeling reliance in decision-making is the prototypical intuition marker.

items.text: I often know the right answer before I can logically explain how I arrived at it.
items.rationale: Pre-logical knowing is a hallmark of intuitive cognitive processing.

items.text: I trust my instincts more than data when the situation is ambiguous.
items.rationale: Instinct over data preference under ambiguity reflects strong intuitive orientation.

items.text: I get strong impressions about people within moments of meeting them, and I'm usually right.
items.rationale: Rapid person-perception with confidence reflects intuitive social cognition.

items.text: When something doesn't feel right, I pay attention to that feeling even if everything looks fine on paper.
items.rationale: Attending to felt sense over objective data is a core intuition construct.

items.text: I experience sudden flashes of insight that seem to come from nowhere.
items.rationale: Spontaneous insight experiences are a defining feature of intuitive cognition.

items.text: I believe that not everything important can be captured by logic and analysis alone.
items.rationale: Valuing non-analytical knowing reflects a philosophical commitment to intuition.

items.text: My body often signals me about a situation before my mind catches up.
items.rationale: Somatic intuition—body-based knowing—is a well-recognized form of intuitive processing.

items.text: I have learned to trust the quiet inner voice that guides me through complex situations.
items.rationale: Inner voice metaphor captures the subjective experience of intuitive guidance.

items.text: People are sometimes surprised by how accurately I can read a situation without much information.
items.rationale: Third-person surprise at accurate low-information judgments reflects intuitive ability.

items.text: I find that my first impression of a situation is usually more accurate than my later analysis.
items.rationale: First-impression superiority belief is a classic intuition construct.

items.text: I can walk into a room and immediately sense the mood without anyone saying a word.
items.rationale: Ambient mood detection reflects intuitive environmental perception.

items.text: I sometimes sense that a relationship is in trouble before any obvious signs appear.
items.rationale: Relational intuition is primarily intuitive but overlaps with Interpersonal Relationships.

items.text: I have a hard time explaining my decision-making process to others because much of it is unconscious.
items.rationale: Difficulty articulating decisions suggests intuitive processing but could reflect low self-awareness.

items.text: I often sense what someone needs emotionally before they express it, and I act on that feeling.
items.rationale: Emotional sensing is intuitive, but acting on it to meet needs maps to Interpersonal Relationships.

items.text: I am constantly seeking out new knowledge, whether through books, courses, or conversations.
items.rationale: Continuous knowledge-seeking across modalities is the core of lifelong learning.

items.text: I believe that personal growth never stops, no matter how old you are.
items.rationale: Age-independent growth belief is a foundational lifelong learning construct.

items.text: I feel restless if I go too long without learning something new.
items.rationale: Restlessness without learning reflects a strong intrinsic learning drive.

items.text: I regularly enroll in courses or workshops to expand my skills and understanding.
items.rationale: Formal learning engagement is a direct behavioral indicator of lifelong learning.

items.text: I view every experience, even failures, as an opportunity to learn something valuable.
items.rationale: Growth mindset applied to failure reflects a deep lifelong learning orientation.

items.text: I enjoy being a beginner at something because it means I have so much to discover.
items.rationale: Comfort with beginner status reflects learning orientation over performance orientation.

items.text: I keep a reading list that grows faster than I can get through it.
items.rationale: Expanding reading list is a concrete behavioral marker of learning appetite.

items.text: I actively seek feedback because I see it as one of the fastest ways to improve.
items.rationale: Feedback-seeking for improvement reflects a learning-oriented cognitive style.

items.text: I find conversations with people from different fields incredibly stimulating because I always learn something.
items.rationale: Cross-disciplinary curiosity reflects broad lifelong learning engagement.

items.text: My colleagues would say I'm the person who is always upskilling or studying something new.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of continuous upskilling captures lifelong learning reputation.

items.text: I believe that intellectual curiosity is one of the most important qualities a person can have.
items.rationale: Valuing curiosity as a top trait reflects a core lifelong learning value.

items.text: I often go down research rabbit holes because one question leads to another.
items.rationale: Recursive curiosity behavior is a strong lifelong learning indicator.

items.text: I find that learning new things helps me come up with more creative solutions at work.
items.rationale: Links learning to creativity, introducing some overlap with Innovativeness.

items.text: I sometimes feel overwhelmed by how much there is to learn and worry I'll never catch up.
items.rationale: Learning overwhelm reflects learning orientation but introduces anxiety that could relate to Mental Health.

items.text: I am motivated to keep learning because I want to be the best version of myself.
items.rationale: Self-improvement motivation drives learning here, but the motivational framing maps to the Motivational factor.

items.text: I regularly check in with myself about how I'm feeling emotionally and mentally.
items.rationale: Emotional self-monitoring is a core mental health awareness behavior.

items.text: I believe that taking care of your mental health is just as important as physical health.
items.rationale: Mental-physical health parity belief is a foundational mental health construct.

items.text: I have developed specific coping strategies for when I feel overwhelmed or anxious.
items.rationale: Coping strategy development reflects active mental health self-management.

items.text: I am not ashamed to seek professional help when my mental health is suffering.
items.rationale: Help-seeking without stigma reflects a healthy mental health orientation.

items.text: I can recognize the early warning signs that my stress levels are becoming unhealthy.
items.rationale: Early stress detection reflects mental health literacy and self-awareness.

items.text: I think society needs to do much more to destigmatize mental health issues.
items.rationale: Advocacy for destigmatization reflects a strong mental health value construct.

items.text: I set boundaries in my life specifically to protect my psychological well-being.
items.rationale: Boundary-setting for psychological protection is a key mental health behavior.

items.text: I understand that my thoughts and emotions are not always accurate reflections of reality.
items.rationale: Cognitive defusion—separating thoughts from reality—reflects mental health sophistication.

items.text: I have learned that suppressing difficult emotions only makes them stronger in the long run.
items.rationale: Understanding emotional suppression effects reflects mental health literacy.

items.text: I prioritize activities that support my emotional resilience, like journaling or therapy.
items.rationale: Deliberate resilience-building activities are direct mental health behaviors.

items.text: I notice how my mental state affects my productivity, relationships, and overall quality of life.
items.rationale: Awareness of mental state's downstream effects reflects integrated mental health cognition.

items.text: I believe that emotional intelligence is a skill that can and should be developed throughout life.
items.rationale: Viewing emotional intelligence as developable reflects a growth-oriented mental health construct.

items.text: I practice mindfulness or meditation to stay grounded and manage my inner world.
items.rationale: Mindfulness is a mental health practice but also overlaps with Health and Wellness.

items.text: I find that talking about my feelings with close friends helps me process difficult experiences.
items.rationale: Emotional processing through conversation is mental health-related but involves Interpersonal Relationships.

items.text: I exercise primarily because of the positive effect it has on my mood and mental clarity.
items.rationale: Exercise for mental benefits is mental health-oriented, but the behavior itself maps to Health and Wellness.

items.text: I have a strong internal compass that tells me what is right and wrong in any situation.
items.rationale: Internal moral compass is the prototypical moral cognition construct.

items.text: I would refuse to do something that conflicts with my ethical principles, even if it cost me personally.
items.rationale: Principled self-sacrifice reflects strong moral commitment.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about what it means to live a morally good life.
items.rationale: Moral reflection and philosophical engagement with ethics is a core moral construct.

items.text: I believe that honesty and integrity should never be compromised for convenience.
items.rationale: Absolute honesty value reflects a strong moral cognitive orientation.

items.text: I feel deeply troubled when I witness injustice, even when it doesn't directly affect me.
items.rationale: Vicarious moral distress at injustice reflects strong moral sensitivity.

items.text: I hold myself to high ethical standards and feel genuine guilt when I fall short.
items.rationale: Self-imposed ethical standards with guilt response reflect internalized moral constructs.

items.text: I consider the ethical implications of my decisions before I consider the practical ones.
items.rationale: Ethics-first decision hierarchy reflects a dominant moral cognitive framework.

items.text: People who know me well would say I am one of the most principled people they know.
items.rationale: Third-person moral reputation captures social perception of moral character.

items.text: I believe that doing the right thing is its own reward, regardless of whether anyone notices.
items.rationale: Intrinsic moral motivation without external validation is a core moral construct.

items.text: I often engage in debates about ethical dilemmas because I find them intellectually and morally important.
items.rationale: Active engagement with ethical dilemmas reflects moral cognitive investment.

items.text: I try to be fair and just in all my dealings, even when it would be easier not to be.
items.rationale: Fairness commitment despite difficulty reflects strong moral orientation.

items.text: I believe that every person has inherent dignity and deserves to be treated with respect.
items.rationale: Universal dignity belief is a foundational moral philosophical construct.

items.text: I sometimes feel torn between what is ethically right and what would benefit the people I love.
items.rationale: Moral-relational tension is primarily moral but introduces Interpersonal Relationships overlap.

items.text: I feel a moral obligation to use my skills and knowledge to help others whenever I can.
items.rationale: Moral obligation to help is ethical but the helping motivation could map to Motivational.

items.text: I am driven to speak up against wrongdoing because I feel a deep sense of purpose in doing so.
items.rationale: Moral advocacy driven by purpose could map to Motivational as the driving force is purpose rather than ethics alone.

items.text: I wake up every day with a clear sense of what I want to accomplish and why it matters.
items.rationale: Daily purpose clarity is a core motivational construct.

items.text: I am deeply driven by goals that are personally meaningful to me.
items.rationale: Intrinsic goal pursuit reflects a strong motivational orientation.

items.text: When I face setbacks, I find the inner strength to keep going because my goals matter to me.
items.rationale: Resilience through goal commitment is a hallmark of motivational cognition.

items.text: I feel most alive when I am working toward something that challenges and excites me.
items.rationale: Vitality through challenge-pursuit reflects intrinsic motivational engagement.

items.text: I set ambitious goals for myself and create detailed plans to achieve them.
items.rationale: Ambitious goal-setting with planning reflects a strong motivational construct.

items.text: I have a strong sense of purpose that guides most of my major life decisions.
items.rationale: Purpose-driven decision-making is a core motivational orientation.

items.text: I can push through discomfort and fatigue when I believe in what I'm working toward.
items.rationale: Perseverance through discomfort for valued goals reflects motivational strength.

items.text: I regularly reflect on whether my daily actions are aligned with my long-term aspirations.
items.rationale: Action-aspiration alignment checking reflects metacognitive motivational processing.

items.text: People around me often comment on how driven and focused I am.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of drive and focus captures motivational reputation.

items.text: I draw energy from visualizing the future I want to create for myself.
items.rationale: Future visualization as an energy source reflects motivational cognitive strategy.

items.text: I believe that discipline and consistency are more important than talent in achieving success.
items.rationale: Discipline-over-talent belief reflects a motivational mindset about achievement.

items.text: I find it easy to stay motivated because I have a clear vision of who I want to become.
items.rationale: Identity-based motivation with clear self-vision is a strong motivational construct.

items.text: My motivation increases when I see that my efforts are contributing to something larger than myself.
items.rationale: Prosocial motivation is motivational but introduces overlap with Moral constructs.

items.text: I stay motivated by constantly setting new learning goals for myself.
items.rationale: Learning-based motivation is motivational but overlaps with Lifelong Learning.

items.text: I am motivated to keep improving my health because I want to be around for the people I love.
items.rationale: Health improvement motivation is motivational, but the health content maps to Health and Wellness and the relational framing to Interpersonal Relationships.

items.text: When I face a difficult challenge, I keep working at it until I find a solution.
items.rationale: Directly reflects persistence in the face of difficulty, a core element of perseverance.

items.text: I don't give up easily, even when others around me have already quit.
items.rationale: Sustained effort despite social pressure to stop is a hallmark of perseverance.

items.text: I believe that most worthwhile accomplishments require sustained effort over a long period.
items.rationale: Cognitive construct linking effort duration to value of outcomes reflects perseverance beliefs.

items.text: People who know me would describe me as someone who never gives up.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral description of persistent character.

items.text: I tend to push through discomfort rather than abandon a task I've started.
items.rationale: Willingness to endure discomfort for task completion is central to perseverance.

items.text: Setbacks motivate me to try harder rather than making me want to stop.
items.rationale: Construing setbacks as motivational rather than discouraging reflects a perseverance mindset.

items.text: I have a track record of finishing what I start, even when it takes much longer than expected.
items.rationale: Behavioral evidence of sustained commitment to completion despite delays.

items.text: I see obstacles as temporary hurdles rather than permanent roadblocks.
items.rationale: Cognitive reframing of obstacles as surmountable is a key construct supporting perseverance.

items.text: When a project becomes tedious, I remind myself of the end goal and keep going.
items.rationale: Self-regulation strategy of goal visualization to maintain effort reflects perseverance.

items.text: I rarely abandon a goal once I've committed to it, no matter how hard it gets.
items.rationale: Strong commitment maintenance under adversity is definitional of perseverance.

items.text: Failure doesn't discourage me—it just tells me I need a different approach.
items.rationale: Adaptive response to failure that sustains effort through strategy change.

items.text: I can maintain focus on a long-term objective even when progress is painfully slow.
items.rationale: Sustained focus despite slow feedback is a core behavioral indicator of perseverance.

items.text: I sometimes wonder if my stubbornness about finishing things is actually holding me back from trying new approaches.
items.rationale: Reflects perseverance but introduces ambiguity about whether rigidity is adaptive or maladaptive.

items.text: I keep practicing a skill even when I seem to have hit a plateau.
items.rationale: Primarily perseverance but could also reflect personal development or growth orientation.

items.text: I stay committed to improving myself even when I don't see immediate results.
items.rationale: The persistence element maps to Perseverance, but the self-improvement focus could map to Personal Development.

items.text: I regularly set aside time to learn new things that help me grow as a person.
items.rationale: Intentional learning for personal growth is a core construct of personal development.

items.text: I actively seek out feedback because I want to understand my blind spots.
items.rationale: Proactive feedback-seeking for self-improvement is central to personal development.

items.text: I view every experience, good or bad, as an opportunity to learn something about myself.
items.rationale: Construing all experiences as learning opportunities reflects a development-oriented mindset.

items.text: I have a clear plan for the skills and qualities I want to develop in myself.
items.rationale: Structured self-improvement planning is a hallmark of personal development orientation.

items.text: I invest in books, courses, or workshops that help me become a better version of myself.
items.rationale: Resource investment in self-improvement is a behavioral indicator of personal development.

items.text: I believe that who I am today should be noticeably different from who I was a year ago.
items.rationale: Expectation of measurable self-change over time reflects a development construct.

items.text: I frequently reflect on my strengths and weaknesses to identify areas for improvement.
items.rationale: Self-reflective assessment for improvement is a core personal development behavior.

items.text: I make it a priority to develop habits that align with the person I want to become.
items.rationale: Intentional habit formation toward an ideal self is central to personal development.

items.text: Others have told me I'm someone who is always working on self-improvement.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of consistent self-improvement behavior.

items.text: I keep a journal or some record of my personal progress and insights.
items.rationale: Tracking personal progress is a concrete behavioral marker of development orientation.

items.text: I think of life as a continuous process of becoming more capable and self-aware.
items.rationale: Philosophical framing of life as ongoing development directly maps to this construct.

items.text: I set specific, measurable goals for my own personal improvement each quarter.
items.rationale: Structured goal-setting for self-improvement is a clear personal development indicator.

items.text: I sometimes feel torn between developing myself personally and focusing on advancing my career.
items.rationale: Primarily personal development but introduces tension with professional growth.

items.text: I try to learn at least one meaningful lesson from every mistake I make.
items.rationale: Learning from mistakes maps to personal development but could also reflect perseverance or personal growth.

items.text: I seek out challenging experiences specifically because they force me to grow beyond my comfort zone.
items.rationale: Challenge-seeking for growth could map to Personal Development or Personal Growth, as both involve expanding one's capacities.

items.text: I feel most alive when I'm stretching beyond what I thought I was capable of.
items.rationale: Emotional engagement with capacity expansion is a core personal growth experience.

items.text: I've gone through difficult periods that fundamentally changed who I am for the better.
items.rationale: Transformative change through adversity is a defining feature of personal growth.

items.text: I embrace uncertainty because I know it often leads to meaningful personal transformation.
items.rationale: Openness to uncertainty as a pathway to transformation reflects a growth-oriented construct.

items.text: Looking back over the past few years, I can see how much I've evolved as a person.
items.rationale: Retrospective recognition of personal evolution is a key indicator of growth awareness.

items.text: I believe that suffering and struggle are often necessary catalysts for becoming a deeper person.
items.rationale: Construing suffering as growth-promoting reflects a personal growth philosophy.

items.text: I've noticed that my values and priorities have shifted significantly as I've matured.
items.rationale: Awareness of value shifts over time reflects ongoing personal growth.

items.text: I'm not the same person I was five years ago, and I'm proud of that.
items.rationale: Positive appraisal of personal change over time is central to growth constructs.

items.text: I find that stepping outside my comfort zone consistently leads to the most meaningful changes in my life.
items.rationale: Linking discomfort to meaningful change is a core personal growth belief.

items.text: I see personal crises not as disasters but as turning points that redirect my life in important ways.
items.rationale: Reframing crises as redirective turning points reflects a growth-oriented cognitive construct.

items.text: My understanding of myself has deepened considerably through life's challenges.
items.rationale: Deepened self-understanding through adversity is a hallmark of personal growth.

items.text: I actively welcome experiences that challenge my existing beliefs and assumptions.
items.rationale: Openness to belief-challenging experiences reflects growth-oriented cognition.

items.text: I think the most important changes in a person happen gradually, through lived experience rather than formal learning.
items.rationale: Valuing experiential over formal learning for change distinguishes growth from development.

items.text: I've become more compassionate and understanding as I've aged, partly because of my own struggles.
items.rationale: Growth in compassion through struggle is personal growth, but the interpersonal element introduces some ambiguity with Personal Relationships.

items.text: I regularly take time to reflect on how my experiences are shaping the person I'm becoming.
items.rationale: Reflective practice maps to growth but also overlaps with Personal Development's self-assessment.

items.text: I deliberately pursue new experiences that expand my perspective, even if they don't have a clear practical benefit.
items.rationale: Pursuing perspective-expanding experiences could map to Personal Growth or Personal Development depending on whether the emphasis is on transformation or skill-building.

items.text: The quality of my close relationships is one of the most important things in my life.
items.rationale: Prioritizing relationship quality is a core construct of personal relationships.

items.text: I invest significant time and energy into maintaining my closest friendships.
items.rationale: Behavioral investment in friendship maintenance directly reflects relationship orientation.

items.text: I believe that deep, authentic connections with others are essential to a meaningful life.
items.rationale: Philosophical belief linking authentic connection to meaning reflects relationship-centered cognition.

items.text: When someone I care about is going through a hard time, I make sure they know I'm there for them.
items.rationale: Supportive behavior toward close others is a key indicator of relationship investment.

items.text: I'm the kind of person who remembers the small details about the people I love.
items.rationale: Attentiveness to personal details reflects deep engagement in close relationships.

items.text: I feel most fulfilled when my relationships with family and friends are strong and healthy.
items.rationale: Linking personal fulfillment to relationship health is central to this construct.

items.text: I'm willing to have difficult conversations to preserve an important relationship.
items.rationale: Willingness to endure discomfort for relationship maintenance reflects strong relational orientation.

items.text: Trust is something I build carefully and consider sacred in my close relationships.
items.rationale: Valuing trust-building in close relationships is a core relational construct.

items.text: I regularly check in with the people who matter most to me, even when life gets busy.
items.rationale: Proactive relationship maintenance behavior despite competing demands.

items.text: I think about how my decisions will affect the people closest to me before I act.
items.rationale: Considering relational impact in decision-making reflects relationship-centered cognition.

items.text: My friends would say I'm one of the most loyal and dependable people they know.
items.rationale: Third-person description of loyalty and dependability in friendships.

items.text: I find it deeply satisfying to help someone I care about work through a personal problem.
items.rationale: Deriving satisfaction from supporting close others reflects relational investment.

items.text: I've learned that being vulnerable with the right people actually strengthens our bond.
items.rationale: Vulnerability as a relational strategy maps to personal relationships but also touches on personal growth.

items.text: I sometimes struggle to balance giving time to my relationships and taking care of my own needs.
items.rationale: Tension between relational investment and self-care introduces ambiguity with self-concept.

items.text: I find that my ability to connect with people one-on-one is quite different from how I handle group situations.
items.rationale: Distinguishes intimate connection from group dynamics, potentially mapping to Social Dynamics.

items.text: I make exercise and physical activity a non-negotiable part of my weekly routine.
items.rationale: Prioritizing regular physical activity is a core behavioral indicator of physical wellness orientation.

items.text: I pay close attention to what I eat because I know nutrition directly affects how I feel and think.
items.rationale: Mindful nutrition linked to cognitive and emotional functioning reflects wellness-oriented cognition.

items.text: Getting enough sleep is something I take very seriously because it affects every other area of my life.
items.rationale: Prioritizing sleep for holistic functioning is a key physical wellness construct.

items.text: I notice that when my body feels good, my mind works better and my mood improves.
items.rationale: Awareness of mind-body connection reflects a wellness-oriented cognitive framework.

items.text: I schedule regular health check-ups and take a proactive approach to my physical health.
items.rationale: Proactive health management behavior is a direct indicator of physical wellness orientation.

items.text: I view taking care of my body as a form of self-respect.
items.rationale: Framing physical care as self-respect reflects a wellness-centered personal construct.

items.text: When I neglect my physical health, I can feel the negative effects in my energy and concentration.
items.rationale: Awareness of health neglect consequences on functioning reflects physical wellness cognition.

items.text: I've built habits around hydration, movement, and rest that keep me functioning at my best.
items.rationale: Systematic wellness habits for optimal functioning are core to physical wellness.

items.text: People around me often comment on how disciplined I am about my health routines.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of health discipline reflects physical wellness orientation.

items.text: I believe that physical health is the foundation upon which everything else in life is built.
items.rationale: Foundational belief about health's primacy is a core wellness construct.

items.text: I actively manage my stress levels through physical activities like walking, yoga, or sports.
items.rationale: Using physical activity for stress management reflects wellness-oriented coping.

items.text: I listen to my body's signals and adjust my activities when I feel run down or unwell.
items.rationale: Body awareness and responsive self-care are key physical wellness behaviors.

items.text: I've noticed that maintaining my physical health requires constant attention and can't be put on autopilot.
items.rationale: Recognizing the ongoing effort of health maintenance is wellness-related but touches on perseverance.

items.text: I try to balance intense work periods with adequate recovery time for my body.
items.rationale: Balancing work and physical recovery maps to wellness but also touches on time management.

items.text: I structure my daily schedule around ensuring I have time for exercise and proper meals.
items.rationale: Scheduling health activities could map to Physical Wellness or Time Management depending on emphasis.

items.text: I actively seek out opportunities to advance my career and develop new professional competencies.
items.rationale: Proactive career advancement and competency development are core professional growth behaviors.

items.text: I have a clear vision of where I want to be professionally in five years.
items.rationale: Long-term professional vision reflects a growth-oriented career construct.

items.text: I regularly update my skills to stay relevant and competitive in my field.
items.rationale: Ongoing skill updating for professional relevance is a direct indicator of professional growth.

items.text: I seek out mentors and professional networks that can help me grow in my career.
items.rationale: Strategic networking and mentorship-seeking for career advancement reflects professional growth.

items.text: I view constructive criticism at work as valuable information that helps me improve professionally.
items.rationale: Positive construal of workplace criticism as growth fuel is central to professional development.

items.text: I take on challenging projects at work specifically because they push me to develop new abilities.
items.rationale: Seeking professional challenges for skill development is a core growth behavior.

items.text: I invest my own time and resources into professional development, even beyond what my employer provides.
items.rationale: Self-directed professional investment beyond requirements reflects strong growth orientation.

items.text: I regularly assess my professional strengths and gaps to guide my career development.
items.rationale: Systematic professional self-assessment for development planning is a key growth indicator.

items.text: My colleagues would describe me as someone who is always looking for ways to improve their work.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of continuous professional improvement seeking.

items.text: I believe that career stagnation is one of the biggest risks to long-term professional satisfaction.
items.rationale: Construing stagnation as a threat reflects a growth-oriented professional mindset.

items.text: I set specific professional goals each year and track my progress toward them.
items.rationale: Annual professional goal-setting with progress tracking is a direct growth behavior.

items.text: I'm willing to step outside my professional comfort zone if it means gaining valuable new experience.
items.rationale: Comfort zone expansion for professional experience reflects growth orientation.

items.text: I find that my drive to grow professionally sometimes comes at the expense of other areas of my life.
items.rationale: Acknowledges professional growth drive but introduces tension with life balance.

items.text: I often read industry publications and attend conferences to stay at the cutting edge of my field.
items.rationale: Industry engagement maps to professional growth but could also reflect general personal development.

items.text: I'm constantly working on becoming better at what I do, whether that's at work or in my personal life.
items.rationale: The inclusion of personal life improvement blurs the line between Professional Growth and Personal Development.

items.text: I have a clear and stable sense of who I am, even when circumstances around me change.
items.rationale: Stable self-identity across contexts is a core element of self-concept.

items.text: I can articulate my core values and beliefs without much hesitation.
items.rationale: Clarity about personal values reflects a well-defined self-concept.

items.text: I know my strengths and limitations and feel comfortable with both.
items.rationale: Balanced self-awareness and acceptance of strengths and weaknesses is central to self-concept.

items.text: I don't feel the need to pretend to be someone I'm not in order to fit in.
items.rationale: Authenticity and resistance to social conformity pressure reflects a secure self-concept.

items.text: My sense of self-worth doesn't depend heavily on what others think of me.
items.rationale: Internal locus of self-worth is a hallmark of a healthy self-concept.

items.text: I feel confident in my identity and don't often question who I fundamentally am.
items.rationale: Identity confidence and stability are core self-concept indicators.

items.text: I understand what motivates me and what drains me, and I make choices accordingly.
items.rationale: Self-knowledge about motivational patterns guiding behavior reflects strong self-concept.

items.text: People who know me well would say I'm very self-aware and genuine.
items.rationale: Third-person validation of self-awareness and authenticity reflects self-concept.

items.text: I have a coherent personal narrative—I understand how my past experiences have shaped who I am today.
items.rationale: Coherent life narrative integration is a sophisticated indicator of self-concept.

items.text: I'm comfortable saying no to things that don't align with my values, even if it disappoints others.
items.rationale: Value-congruent boundary-setting reflects a secure and well-defined self-concept.

items.text: I rarely compare myself to others because I have my own internal standards for success.
items.rationale: Internal success standards rather than social comparison reflects strong self-concept.

items.text: I feel grounded in who I am, which helps me navigate difficult social situations without losing myself.
items.rationale: Self-stability in challenging social contexts reflects a secure self-concept.

items.text: Sometimes I wonder whether the person I present to the world truly reflects who I am inside.
items.rationale: Self-concept questioning about authenticity; the doubt itself is informative but introduces ambiguity.

items.text: I've spent a lot of time thinking about what kind of person I want to be and aligning my actions with that vision.
items.rationale: Intentional identity construction maps to self-concept but overlaps with personal development.

items.text: Understanding who I am has been a journey that has also transformed how I relate to others.
items.rationale: Self-understanding journey maps to Self-concept, but the relational transformation element could map to Personal Relationships.

items.text: I'm good at reading the mood of a room and understanding the unspoken dynamics between people.
items.rationale: Perceptiveness about group mood and interpersonal dynamics is central to social dynamics awareness.

items.text: I notice how power and influence shift between people in group settings.
items.rationale: Awareness of power dynamics in groups is a core social dynamics construct.

items.text: I understand that people behave differently depending on the social context they're in.
items.rationale: Recognition of context-dependent behavior reflects sophisticated social dynamics understanding.

items.text: I can usually tell when there's tension between people, even if nobody is talking about it.
items.rationale: Detecting implicit interpersonal tension is a key social dynamics perception skill.

items.text: I'm fascinated by how group norms form and how they influence individual behavior.
items.rationale: Interest in group norm formation and influence reflects social dynamics orientation.

items.text: I can identify who the real influencers are in a group, regardless of their formal role or title.
items.rationale: Distinguishing informal influence from formal authority reflects social dynamics acuity.

items.text: I pay attention to how alliances and subgroups form within larger social settings.
items.rationale: Awareness of coalition formation is a sophisticated social dynamics construct.

items.text: I understand that what people say publicly and what they believe privately are often quite different.
items.rationale: Recognizing public-private belief discrepancies reflects social dynamics insight.

items.text: I'm aware of how social hierarchies affect the way people communicate and make decisions.
items.rationale: Understanding hierarchy's impact on communication is central to social dynamics.

items.text: I can sense when a group is about to reach a tipping point in a discussion or conflict.
items.rationale: Anticipating group tipping points reflects advanced social dynamics perception.

items.text: I think a lot about how social environments shape people's behavior, sometimes more than their personality does.
items.rationale: Situationist perspective on behavior reflects a social dynamics cognitive framework.

items.text: Others have told me I have an unusual ability to understand what's really going on beneath the surface in social situations.
items.rationale: Third-person recognition of social perceptiveness maps to social dynamics.

items.text: I often find myself mediating between people because I can see both sides of a social conflict.
items.rationale: Mediation reflects social dynamics understanding but also involves social skills in execution.

items.text: I notice that certain people consistently change the energy of a group just by being present.
items.rationale: Observing individual impact on group energy is social dynamics but could relate to personal relationships awareness.

items.text: I use my understanding of group dynamics to help facilitate better conversations and outcomes in team settings.
items.rationale: Applying dynamics knowledge to facilitate groups could map to Social Dynamics understanding or Social Skills application.

items.text: I find it easy to start conversations with people I've never met before.
items.rationale: Ease of initiating conversation with strangers is a core social skill.

items.text: I'm good at making people feel comfortable and at ease when they're around me.
items.rationale: Ability to put others at ease reflects interpersonal social competence.

items.text: I can adapt my communication style depending on who I'm talking to.
items.rationale: Communication adaptability is a key social skill reflecting interpersonal flexibility.

items.text: I'm skilled at expressing my thoughts clearly and persuasively in social situations.
items.rationale: Clear and persuasive social communication is a direct social skill indicator.

items.text: I know how to listen actively so that the other person feels truly heard and understood.
items.rationale: Active listening that conveys understanding is a fundamental social skill.

items.text: I can navigate awkward social situations with grace and help others feel less uncomfortable.
items.rationale: Managing social awkwardness gracefully is a sophisticated social skill.

items.text: I'm effective at resolving disagreements between people by finding common ground.
items.rationale: Conflict resolution through common ground identification is a key social skill.

items.text: I can read people's body language and facial expressions to gauge how they're really feeling.
items.rationale: Nonverbal communication reading is a foundational social skill.

items.text: I'm comfortable giving and receiving compliments in a way that feels natural and sincere.
items.rationale: Natural compliment exchange reflects social ease and interpersonal competence.

items.text: People often come to me when they need someone to help smooth over a tense interaction.
items.rationale: Being sought out for interpersonal smoothing reflects recognized social skill.

items.text: I know how to assert my needs in a conversation without coming across as aggressive or demanding.
items.rationale: Assertive yet non-aggressive communication is a sophisticated social skill.

items.text: I'm good at introducing people to each other and helping new social connections form.
items.rationale: Social bridging and connection facilitation is a clear social skill.

items.text: I've gotten better at social interactions over the years by consciously practicing and reflecting on what works.
items.rationale: Deliberate social skill improvement maps here but also touches on personal development.

items.text: I can usually tell when someone needs space versus when they want to talk, and I respond accordingly.
items.rationale: Reading social needs and responding appropriately is a social skill but also reflects social dynamics awareness.

items.text: I'm perceptive about what's happening in a group and I use that awareness to contribute more effectively to conversations.
items.rationale: Group perceptiveness could map to Social Skills (application) or Social Dynamics (awareness).

items.text: I use a planning system to organize my tasks and commitments so nothing falls through the cracks.
items.rationale: Using organizational systems for task management is a core time management behavior.

items.text: I'm good at estimating how long tasks will take and planning my day accordingly.
items.rationale: Accurate time estimation and daily planning are fundamental time management skills.

items.text: I prioritize my tasks based on importance and urgency rather than just doing whatever comes up first.
items.rationale: Strategic prioritization is a core cognitive construct of time management.

items.text: I rarely feel overwhelmed by my to-do list because I break large projects into manageable steps.
items.rationale: Task decomposition to prevent overwhelm is a key time management strategy.

items.text: I set deadlines for myself, even when external deadlines aren't imposed, to keep myself on track.
items.rationale: Self-imposed deadlines for self-regulation reflect proactive time management.

items.text: I'm disciplined about avoiding distractions when I need to focus on important work.
items.rationale: Distraction management for focused work is a core time management behavior.

items.text: I review my schedule at the beginning of each week to make sure I'm allocating my time wisely.
items.rationale: Weekly schedule review for time allocation is a direct time management practice.

items.text: I'm usually punctual and meet my deadlines because I plan ahead and build in buffer time.
items.rationale: Punctuality through advance planning and buffer time reflects effective time management.

items.text: I know when to say no to new commitments because I understand the limits of my available time.
items.rationale: Commitment boundary-setting based on time awareness is a key management skill.

items.text: People who work with me would say I'm one of the most organized and efficient people they know.
items.rationale: Third-person recognition of organization and efficiency reflects time management.

items.text: I batch similar tasks together to minimize context-switching and maximize my productivity.
items.rationale: Task batching for efficiency is a sophisticated time management technique.

items.text: I regularly evaluate how I spend my time and look for ways to eliminate waste or inefficiency.
items.rationale: Time auditing and efficiency optimization are core time management behaviors.

items.text: I find that good time management gives me more freedom to enjoy leisure activities without guilt.
items.rationale: Linking time management to leisure enjoyment is relevant but introduces a wellness/balance element.
